Russia sees push for return of official censorship
subhead: As the Kremlin increasingly restricts the flow of ideas, those nostalgic for the USSR are calling for the reinstatement of the state body that once decided what could and could not be published. They argue that entrusting this job 'to professionals rather than bureaucrats' would protect against arbitrariness.

subhead: According to the US Tsunami Warning Center, waves one to three meters above tidal levels are possible along certain coasts of Chile, Costa Rica, French Polynesia, Guam, Oregon, Hawaii, Japan, and other islands in the Pacific.
byline: Le Monde with AP and AFP

title: Spike Lee, Benin's star ambassador to attract the Afro-descendant diaspora
subhead: The American filmmaker and his wife, Tonya Lewis Lee, have been appointed as ambassadors to the diaspora in the United States. The Beninese government has also launched a platform, 'My Afro Origins,' allowing people to apply for Beninese citizenship.
byline: By Sélène Agapé and Aby Faye

title: Cybèle Idelot's Ile-de-France adventure: from Hollywood childhood to kitchen gardens
subhead: 'Chefs' gardens' (1/5). The 50-year-old chef transformed a former coaching inn in Yvelines, just outside of Paris, into a domain that now welcomes guests to bed-and-breakfast rooms, a bistronomic restaurant, and above all, a vegetable garden that allows the restaurant to be self-sufficient.

title: Low-calorie French pastries struggle to win over chefs and consumers
subhead: While French pastries are renowned worldwide for their refined taste and aesthetic appeal, their nutritional value could place them in the category of junk food. However, some pastry chefs are attempting to create cakes that are lower in sugar and fat.

subhead: 'Being 20 in West Berlin' (2/6). In the late 1970s, Karin Wieland fled her small German town to live communally in an abandoned building in Kreuzberg, throwing herself into every cause of the era.

title: 'We often go to bed on empty stomachs': In Ethiopia's Afar region, hunger takes its toll
subhead: In northern Ethiopia, the freeze on USAID threatens to worsen food insecurity, already affecting thousands of families impacted by land drying up.
byline: By Marlène Panara (Abala, Ethiopia, special correspondent)

title: Is there a genocide in Gaza? Why legal experts are split
subhead: Genocide, as defined by the 1948 convention, requires both certain criminal acts to be committed and genocidal intent. While the requisite acts have been proven in Gaza, legal scholars are divided over the intent. South Africa has filed a genocide complaint against Israel with the International Court of Justice in The Hague.
